content.title: Minimal Change Disease
content.summary: Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and a significant cause in adults. It is characterized by normal light microscopy, negative immunofluorescence, and diffuse podocyte foot process effacement on electron microscopy. MCD is highly responsive to corticosteroids with excellent long-term prognosis.
key_points: Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (70-90%)
Electron microscopy: Diffuse podocyte foot process effacement
Relapse common (50-75%) but does not progress to CKD
content.statement: Minimal change disease is a podocytopathy causing heavy proteinuria with normal light microscopy findings, highly responsive to steroids, representing the most common nephrotic syndrome etiology in children.

explanation.intuition: Think of podocytes as the velcro-like fasteners between the kidney's filtration membrane. In MCD, something (possibly T-cell derived factors) causes these fasteners to flatten out and lose their grip, allowing proteins to leak through. The damage is so subtle it's invisible under regular microscopy - you need the electron microscope to see the flattened 'feet.'
explanation.key_insight: MCD is a 'diagnosis of exclusion on biopsy' - the pathognomonic finding is seeing NOTHING abnormal on light microscopy and IF while seeing diffuse foot process effacement on EM. The 90% steroid response rate makes empiric treatment reasonable in children without biopsy, but adults typically undergo biopsy to exclude FSGS.
explanation.technical_details: The pathogenic 'permeability factor' remains elusive but appears to be T-cell derived. Circulating factors increase glomerular permeability to albumin by disrupting podocyte slit diaphragms (nephrin, podocin). Secondary causes include NSAIDs, lithium, Hodgkin lymphoma, and allergic reactions.

definitions_glossary.minimal_change_disease: Nephrotic syndrome with normal LM, negative IF, and diffuse foot process effacement on EM
definitions_glossary.podocyte: Specialized epithelial cell with foot processes forming the slit diaphragm
definitions_glossary.foot_process_effacement: Flattening and fusion of podocyte foot processes; hallmark of podocytopathy
definitions_glossary.slit_diaphragm: Specialized junction between podocyte foot processes; filtration barrier
definitions_glossary.steroid_responsive: Complete remission of proteinuria within 8-16 weeks of corticosteroid therapy
definitions_glossary.steroid_dependent: Relapse during steroid taper or within 2 weeks of stopping
definitions_glossary.frequently_relapsing: Two or more relapses within 6 months or 4+ per year
definitions_glossary.nephrin: Key slit diaphragm protein; mutations cause congenital nephrotic syndrome
definitions_glossary.podocin: Slit diaphragm protein; mutations cause steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome
definitions_glossary.permeability_factor: Hypothesized circulating factor causing proteinuria in MCD
definitions_glossary.secondary_MCD: MCD associated with drugs (NSAIDs), malignancy (Hodgkin), or allergy

pathophysiology.mechanism: T-cell dysfunction produces circulating factors that damage podocytes, causing foot process effacement and loss of the size-selective filtration barrier, resulting in massive proteinuria

podocyte_injury.primary: Idiopathic - presumed T-cell derived permeability factor

pathology.light_microscopy: Normal glomeruli (may show mild mesangial hypercellularity)
pathology.immunofluorescence: Negative (no IgG, IgM, IgA, C3 deposits)
pathology.electron_microscopy: Diffuse foot process effacement (>80% of GBM length)

clinical_presentation: Sudden onset severe edema (periorbital, lower extremity, genital)
diagnostic_criteria.biopsy_in_adults: Typically performed before treatment to exclude FSGS

differential_diagnosis: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) - scarring on LM

initial_therapy.children: Prednisone 60 mg/m²/day (max 80mg) for 4-6 weeks, then 40 mg/m² every other day for 4-6 weeks
initial_therapy.adults: Prednisone 1 mg/kg/day (max 80mg) for minimum 4 weeks until remission, then taper over 6 months

relapse_treatment.frequent_relapse_or_steroid_dependent: Add calcineurin inhibitor (cyclosporine, tacrolimus) or cyclophosphamide or rituximab
relapse_treatment.steroid_resistant: Calcineurin inhibitor ± low-dose prednisone; consider rituximab

definition.@value: A cause of nephrotic syndrome characterized by normal light microscopy, negative immunofluorescence, and diffuse podocyte foot process effacement on electron microscopy, highly responsive to corticosteroids

scopeNote.@value: Covers pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment of primary and secondary MCD

medicalCode.description: Unspecified nephritic syndrome with minor glomerular abnormality

learning_objectives: Identify MCD as the most common pediatric nephrotic syndrome cause
Describe the pathognomonic biopsy triad: normal LM, negative IF, diffuse FPE on EM
Explain why children may be treated empirically without biopsy
Design treatment strategy for steroid-responsive vs resistant disease
List secondary causes including NSAIDs and Hodgkin lymphoma
clinical_pearls: Children with typical nephrotic syndrome: empiric steroids, biopsy only if steroid-resistant
Adults: always biopsy before treatment to exclude FSGS
NSAID-induced MCD: resolves with drug discontinuation
Hodgkin lymphoma: MCD may precede, accompany, or follow lymphoma diagnosis
Relapse is common (50-75%) but long-term prognosis is EXCELLENT
common_misconceptions: MCD only occurs in children - 10-15% of adult nephrotic syndrome
MCD progresses to FSGS - they are separate diseases (though tip lesion may overlap)
Steroid resistance means poor prognosis - calcineurin inhibitors often effective
